Award.AwardTitle: A Novel Anchoring Mechanism for Prokaryotic Surface Proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Archaea are prokaryotic organisms that are distinct from bacteria and although they are well known for the ability of many species to thrive in extreme environments, they are ubiquitous and can be found even in our gut and on our skin. Many cell surface proteins are essential to cellular functions (processes such as nutrient uptake, surface adhesion, and mating) and they must be effectively anchored to the cell surface in order to carry out their functions. In archaea, these attachment mechanisms are poorly understood and this project will characterize a novel surface protein anchoring mechanism that is also predicted to be used by many bacteria. The research project team will engage in science education to inspire an interest in science in young children, particularly those in underserved schools in West Philadelphia. The PI will develop microbiology experiments that can be utilized by schools with limited financial resources, and the researchers will participate in both in-class instruction and teacher-training workshops hosted by the University of Pennsylvania.


In silico data suggest that many prokaryotes use a previously unknown mechanism to covalently link the C-terminus of a substrate to a lipid in the cell membrane. In archaea, this anchoring mechanism is likely catalyzed by an archaeosortase (ArtA) in a process that is reminiscent of the anchoring of surface proteins by the evolutionarily distinct bacterial sortase, an enzyme that processes and covalently links the C-termini of substrates to the cell wall. In vivo evidence supports the hypothesis that the Haloferax volcanii S-layer glycoprotein is processed and covalently linked to the lipid bilayer in an ArtA-dependent manner and has also revealed that other ArtA substrates play vital roles in important biological processes. The goal of the proposed research is to determine the specific roles that this ArtA-dependent anchoring mechanism plays in H. volcanii cellular processes, using biochemical, mass spectrometric, genetic and microscopic approaches. The proposed research will: 1) characterize post-translational modifications involving ArtA in greater detail; 2) determine structure-function relationships for ArtA, including the importance of a putative catalytic amino acid triad, as well as identifying other proteins that interact with ArtA; and 3) characterize the functional roles played by ArtA substrates in cellular processes such as mating, motility and adhesion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Archaea are prokaryotic organisms, distinct from bacteria in many ways, but similar in others, and although they are primarily known for the ability of numerous species to thrive under extreme conditions, they are actuallyubiquitous, being found where ever life exists on earth, including the human gut and skin. Cell surface proteins play essential roles in crucialcellular processes, such asnutrient uptake, surface adhesion, and biofilm formation.Therefore, to ensurethat these processes are carried out efficiently, mechanisms that allowtheseproteins to becorrectly anchored to the surface must be in place. In archaea, these mechanisms are not well understood. The work completed with funding obtained for the previous NSF grant focused on characterizing a novel surface protein anchoring mechanism, that, based on in silicodata, requires the participation ofa novel peptidase, Archaeosortase (ArtA). As was proposed, using a diverse set of approaches, the predicted ArtA pathway has now been characterized in more detail, with confirmation that ArtA is, in fact, a key component in a novel protein anchoring pathway. Moreover, two additional components were identified as critical for lipid anchoring, and this pathway was shown to be used to anchor a diverse set of proteins to the surface membrane. These findings not only expand our basic understanding of archaeal cell biology but also will likely lead to the development of novel biotech applications, such as improved liposomes for drug delivery. 

In addition to successfully achieving the goals set forth for the NSF funding period, this research, through extensive screens and selections carried out by undergraduate and high school students, also led to the uncovering of intriguing findings suggesting novel mechanisms, involving the release and/or reorganization/relocalization of membrane-anchored lipoproteins, that facilitate the morphological transitions between rod-shaped and disk-shaped cells. Finally, funding from this grant supported work that focused on the characterization of a specific set of surface-anchored proteins required for adhesion and biofilm formation. Data obtained from this work suggest that not only the differential expression patterns but also the post-translational modifications of surface proteins are critical for regulating transitions between the free-swimming state of planktonic cells and the sessile state of biofilm-embedded cells. This insight led to the application of cutting edge methods and tools, like quantitative proteomics, in a project in the PIs lab that will detail these differential changes in archaeal and bacterial systems.   

            The research project team involved in this work also engaged in a science education program designed to inspire an interest in science among young children, particularly those who attend underserved schools in West Philadelphia. In particular, the PI, together with high school students and undergraduate students, developed microbiology experiments that can be utilized in classrooms having limited financial resources. The researchers also helped train teachers in how to present and explain these experiments in workshops that were hosted by the University of Pennsylvania.
